newsitem.title: USA: CSX sees coal flat, rate pressures ongoing.
newsitem.headline: CSX sees coal flat, rate pressures ongoing.

text.p: Coal shipments remain flat, meaning challenges for CSX Corp's railroad division, and rate pressures continue to plague the company's Sea-Land division, CSX said Tuesday at a presentation of second quarter results.

Merchandise traffic such as autos, chemicals and metals is growing faster than the industrial production index, but slow electricity demand and a strong dollar are hurting coal exports, said John Anderson, executive vice president of sales and marketing at CSX's rail division, CSX Transportation.
Coal shipments compose about a third of the revenues for CSX Transportation.
Given these factors, CSX Chairman John Snow said the company is "reasonably optimistic," but also sees reason "to be a little cautious."
CSX Transportation generated $1.253 billion in operating revenues in the second quarter. CSX's container shipping division generated $1.011 billion in operating revenues.
In all, the company reported second quarter revenues of $2.678 billion and earnings of $1.04 per share, including $0.09 a share impact from costs associated with its acquisition of Conrail.
Wall Street was expecting the company to report second quarter earnings of $1.07 a share, according to First Call estimates.
Snow said rate pressures in the containiner shipping industry should begin to ease in nine to 18 months, meaning an easier time for Sea-Land.
"We're confident that in nine, 12 or 18 months we're going to be in a much more favorable rate environment," Snow said.
Snow added that Sea Land handled more load in the second quarter, even while experiencing a drop in operating expenses.

When asked if the unit would beat a goal of $350 million in 1997 operating earnings, Sea-Land spokesman Clint Eisenhauer said the unit is "comfortable" it will exceed last year's operating earnings of $318 million.
